comments.commentBody:
Invest in education!

Too much money is already spend on education. The problem here is that much of that money is wasted as it is poured into an inherently dysfunctional public education system.

The public schools should not be run for the benefit of those employed in them -- as they now are. Public schools should be run for the benefit of the children and the local communities that pay for the service.

The problem is a lack of aggregate demand.  The Fed would not need to continue on this extraordinary and, yes, potentially dangerous policy if instead of continuous fiscal contraction we stepped on the fiscal accelerated to rebuild infrastructure and invest in education.

I support abortion rights as much as anyone, but clearly some people ARE using abortion as a form of birth control -- like the woman the writer met who was having her ninth abortion. There is no excuse for that.
It's somewhat rare but it's not a lie.  I've known more than one woman who was careless with contraception because they thought (mistakenly) that this would be an easy back up plan.

Actually the author says that women at the clinic with her at the time, had had as many as EIGHT abortions.

That would be horrifying in a 50 year old, but these were young women. That is probably an abortion every year. How can you NOT call that the use of abortion as birth control?

Thank you for shining light on the lie that women have abortions as a form of contraception. No, women do not. Abortion is not an easily arrived at decision and is it the last choice one wishes to make. Sometimes, it is the only rational one for myriad reasons. I will never judge someone's choice. I do not know what she is experiencing. It is not for me to seek to control others, only to support and respect whatever another woman wants as her right to exercise autonomous decision making as an adult.

That said, you were such an innocent child to think you could romanticize any medical procedure!

@Tom, I have to ask... what makes Klinsmann a great coach? His resume as a coach, he took Germany to a 3rd place finish, but Germany finish in the top 6 more often than not, and now has taken the US team to a 1-1-2 record.
He may be a good coach after all , but his resume ain't there yet.

This is a very good article. Klinsmann is head and shoulders above the other coaches that we have had, as is shown by his resume.
Soccer has become more and more popular and that trend is not going to stop. It has been a long time coming, but the train is rolling down the tracks and it won't be stopped. We have progressed from having soccer geeks watch perhaps one game of the WC ever 4 years (due to broadcast availability) to being able to watch every single game either on cable or free on your phone.
Glazer (the deceased owner of the NFL Buchaneers bought Manchester United because he wanted a world soccer brand in his portfolio for the future).
Klinsmann will continue to be a great coach for the team and he will be great for soccer in the USA in general.
Same as every other league table: points, goal differential, goals scored.  We ended up with 4 points and a -1 goal differential, ahead of only Greece among the teams eliminated in the round of 16.
Mike with all due respect. What countries play baseball.. the US, Canada, Cuba, Japan, Dominican Republic and Venezuela. OK so maybe I missed a few. But what's the total like 12 countries?

Why not just start with examining the German football development system? Its resurgency these past 3 WC's owes a great deal to a revamping in Youth talent identification and training instituted just over a decade ago. One of the major factors in their improvement in that area were the influential ideas of their head coach of that time - a fellow by the name of Klinsmann...
Revamp? Re-invent? JK already knows what to do, and no doubt has been working on it since 2011, when he was installed as US coach.
Give those newly identified kids 5-10 years (they don't grow up overnight) and I think you'll see a different U.S. skill set 2 World Cups hence.

Agreed. Costa Rica is doing something right. I hope that people also realize that it is already a success to make it into the final 32. I did not see Austria, Sweden, Norway,  Scotland etc. in Brazil. They all have long standing traditions of soccer.
i'd like to know that too.  maybe it's some kind of tally of overall record and goal differential.  ?
On the field -- four games: two losses, one tie, one win,
One win one draw and two losses says it all. A poor showing from a country of over 315 million. Little Belgium gave them a lesson they should never forget.

Hey look, they made it into the round of 16, out of a field of over 200!

That's NOT success?

How about writing about actual on-the-field play and leaving the pot-stirring attempts at "controversy" to the tabloids?
i think it might be okay, but only if all major leagers were juicing, to provide a level playing field.
Did you see him play last year? Yangervis Solarte is indistinguishable from 2013 A-Roid...
It's torture watching the hapless Yanks this year.  Would it be so terrible to have ARod on the team swinging for the fences? Steroids or not?
Glad to see I'm not the only one who calls the MLB commissioner BeelzeBud Selig!

After Beezlebud Selig is enshrined in Cooperstown all actual and suspected steroid users should be eligible for the Hall of Fame. They can be enshrined in the post-1995 Steroids Wing of the HOF. Over the past half century more football players than baseball players have used steroids. I was reading about amphetamines baseball locker rooms in The Sporting News back in the Sixties. Amphetamines are to baseball what chewing tobacco, bubble gum and apple pie (think of Tug McGraw and cakes!) are.

If there are going to be players with steroid exemptions they should be publicly known. Where is the Sunshine Law when you need it? You cannot spot a steroids user without a program/score card!

Therapeutic replacement of testosterone levels is controversial --given that even a few readings of low testosterone do not mean that levels themselves are consistently low. In young persons, outside of a double orchiectomy, needed in case of cancer in both testes, testosterone levels are never low...

Unless of course, the person was exposed to high levels of artificial testosterone, so high that its own testosterone levels would drop --but in this case, waiting for four months or so is the prescribed treatment (just Google it --this is a very common problem in bodybuilding).

It is exceedingly questionable why Mr. Rodriguez was prescribed supplementation versus letting this come back on its own, unless of course, the point was the anabolic effects of testosterone.

"Exemptions to use such substances in baseball, Manfred went on to say in the testimony, were 'very rare.'”
On the other hand, one out of every six major league baseball players have a "diagnosis" of ADHD, allowing them an exemption to use the stimulants Adderall or Ritalin.
Calling exemptions "rare" is thoroughly disingenuous. It depends upon what drug you're talking about.
Israel has no constitution and is a 'Theocracy' (like Iran) rather than a true Democracy, votes notwithstanding.
so PEDs don't work, is what you're saying. so they're a non issue.  maybe its an aesthetic thing Alonzo Mourning was going after??
My understanding is that NBA players have four random drug tests during the year. So it is after the fourth one, knowing that there will not be another, that the window for PED abuse opens wide.
where is the proof of "painfully obvious PED use" among the NBA?

While I applaud the continuing attention on Baseball and PEDs, which is mostly about the past, I am mystified by the deafening silence on the painfully obvious PED use by some of the NBA's leading players today.  Why has there been no book like "Blood Sport" on the NBA?  The comparison photos, statistics, and routine super-human feats scream PED use by some marquis NBA players.  I was delighted to see the San Antonio Spurs win the NBA title last month in large part because they are the rare top-tier team for which their star(s) do/does not project classic signs of PED use.
Well 90% of people who work in offices do - everyone office I know showed yesterday's game on a big screen.

This is a silly debate about taste.  My guess is most Americans don't dislike soccer, they are just apathetic, as am I.  It is like many of the Olympic events, attracting attention by patriotism and curiosity while it is happening but back to niche sport when not.  To each his own.

I had very mild occasional asthma, as many people do. Never needed medication for it. Then one winter I got the flu, the real flu, not just a bad cold. I had a hacking cough for weeks. When the illness finally passed my lungs were damaged by the flu. My asthma went from occasional/mild to moderate/severe/chronic. I had to take inhaled steroids daily for about a decade afterwards. Eventually it calmed down again and I no longer need asthma medication. You bet I get a flu shot every year now.
Pertussis can be transmitted before a person becomes symptomatic, so having grandpa avoid the baby if he is sick is not enough in the event that he becomes infected.

Except expansionary monetary policy is only non-inflationary when the economy is in a liquidity trap. This doesn't occur often.

And except that to replace the revenue derived from, say generously, the 75% of federal taxable economic activity that no one wishes to slow down would require the issuance of some 1,000 billion of bonds. It's highly doubtful there are buyers for that much plus the 680 billion of bonds required to fund the deficit, especially since offered interest rates are stipulated to be low. (These are the CBO numbers for 2013, excluding corporate and social insurance taxes.) Since our government is pretty much just a very well-armed insurance company anyway (Defense and Medicare spending alone equals about 85% of the total revenue from federal individual income tax) it's going to be very tough to borrow enough to support those activities.

I'm afraid neither party is going to be able to ride this approach anywhere. On the other hand, increasing progressive income tax revenue while increasing government spending to restore healthy demand is very highly likely to increase employment which would generate additional tax revenue. (It would also reduce the amount of needless misery in the country, just by the way.)

If we're going to fantasize about policy changes that could improve things, I prefer a fantasy that is only politically unfeasible to one that is logically unworkable.
That was after they broke up the gerrymandered districts the Democrats had set up.

When you lay lie a rug by not voting you encourage the other team to step on you, so they take their power AND yours when they vote.  Not voting is beyond dumb and yet people do it because they say it doesn't matter. But by not voting in2010 you allowed the Republicans to win and to gerrymander districts to take away what power you didn't want to use.

So, have premiums deducted from one's paycheck is not considered "paying" now, WrongWay?

I find it fascinating how GOPers automatically assume that someone who contributes to their medical insurance premiums is asking for handouts. No, they are paying for medical coverage, which includes their reproductive systems.

It's obvious that Uly is not FOR Climate change. Uly is FOR admitting that climate change is happening instead of the asinine denial of some
Republicans in the face of a huge amount of solid scientific evidence. Unmentioned is that Uly ( and I ) are against the points of views of people who deny facts and who are obtuse on many levels.

If the GOP retakes the Senate and keeps the House, they will impeach our President. That's what this lawsuit threat is all about.

Read Jonathan Capehart's excellent piece, How President Obama Will Be Impeached.

http://www.rimaregas.com/2014/06/how-president-obama-will-be-impeached-t...

The easy money had little to do with interest rates. It had everything to do with 100% financing, negative amortization, and fraudulent underwriting. The Fed was aware this was going on as early as 2003 and did nothing about it.

I know what Yellen is saying. But, I do not believe her. Particularly the part about allowing risk takers to fail. Remember who she works for.
